metadata.case_name: All India Film Corporation Ltd. & Ors. v. Raja Gyan Nath

facts.text: The property in dispute is a building in Jullundur City known as Odeon Cinema (formerly Chitra Talkies), constructed in 1933 on land measuring 3 kanals and 17 marlas.
Original owner Azim Baksh migrated to Pakistan in 1947 and the property was declared evacuee property.
On January 21, 1946, Azim Baksh mortgaged the building with possession for Rs. 70,000 to Malawa Ram and Gainda Mal.
On January 22, 1946, Azim Baksh took the building on lease from the mortgagees for 11 months at Rs. 162.8 annas and executed a rent note.

On February 8, 1946, the rent note was cancelled with endorsement: 'With the consent of Lal Gainda Ram and Malawa Ram, the said rent-deed has been cancelled. Rent for one month may be included in the mortgage amount. The mortgagees are entitled to carry on the aforesaid cinema in any way they like or may give the same on lease to anybody else. I shall have no objection.'
Previously, Azim Baksh had rented the building to Sant Ram and Sita Ram on Rs. 150 per month.
After release of the property, mortgagees leased it to Sita Ram and Sohan Lal on Rs. 200 per month, terminated on July 26, 1950.

In August 1951, mortgagees leased it to All India Film Corporation Ltd. (appellant No. 1, defendant No. 2) on Rs. 250 per month (Ex. D.2 W.2/1) for 5 years from September 15, 1951 to September 14, 1956, renewable for 10 years by yearly renewals on same terms; lessee given full right to use, sub-lease etc.
Malawa Ram and Gainda Mal partitioned their property; the house fell to Gainda Mal's share.
Head lessee sub-let premises to defendants 3 to 9 on May 16, 1952 at Rs. 1,250 per month, including use of cinema machinery etc. installed by head lessee.
Gainda Mal applied under Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 for separation of his interest.
Competent Officer by order dated August 25, 1955 determined mortgage charge as Rs. 90,807.4 annas and ordered sale of the building and land together with another plot.
Raja Gyan Nath (respondent/plaintiff) purchased the cinema with land (3 kanals 17 marlas) for Rs. 65,000 on December 3, 1955; sale certificate issued March 3, 1956.
Mortgage charge paid off on April 19, 1958.
Raja Gyan Nath filed suit for possession from head lessee and sub-lessees on August 5, 1959, and mesne profits at Rs. 1,250 per month.
Sub-lessees claimed benefit of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 3 of 1949.
Plaintiff later gave up claim to cinema machinery, furniture and fittings.
Trial Judge decreed possession in full, mesne profits at Rs. 500 per month, half costs disallowed.
Defendants 2, 4, 10 and 11 appealed to High Court; plaintiff cross-objected for mesne profits at Rs. 1,250 with 6% interest and remaining costs.
Punjab High Court by judgment dated March 19, 1963 affirmed decree, reduced mesne profits to Rs. 250 per month from date of suit till possession with 6% interest.
High Court granted certificate to both sides; appeals filed in Supreme Court.
Annual rent of building assessed at Rs. 10,800 for 1950-55.
Head lessee invested Rs. 60,000 equipping with cinema machinery; sub-lease rent Rs. 1,250 pm.
Building without fittings and passage land sold for Rs. 65,000.

legal_issues.text: Did the tenancy created by the mortgagee in possession survive the termination of the mortgagee interest so as to be binding on the purchaser?
Whether the defendants were protected by the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 3 of 1949?
Whether plaintiff was entitled to possession before the expiry of the full term of the lease with right to renewals?

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendants (lessees) were protected by East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949; entitled to possession till expiry of lease term with renewals; mesne profits should not be awarded or lower.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff not entitled to full mesne profits at Rs. 1,250; cross-objection for higher mesne profits.

respondent_arguments.text: Tenancy did not survive termination of mortgage; no protection under Rent Act; entitled to possession and mesne profits at Rs. 1,250 pm.
Rent Restriction Act definitions of landlord/tenant do not apply post-termination of mortgage.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949; Evacuee Interest Separation Act, 1951 s.10

court_reasoning.text: No person can confer better title than he has; mortgagee lease terminates with mortgage interest under s.111(c) TPA unless mortgagor concurs or fresh lease; exception under s.76(a) for prudent management does not apply to long-term low-rent urban lease.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lease not an act of prudence: 5+10 years at Rs.250 pm (effectively Rs.150 for building) too low compared to market (assessed Rs.10,800 annual, sub-lease Rs.1,250).

court_reasoning.text: No surviving tenancy post-sale and redemption under Evacuee Act s.10; purchaser as mortgagor can claim end of mortgagee actions; no landlord-tenant relation for Rent Act to apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mortgage extinction unites interests; Rent Act definitions require subsisting tenancy.

court_reasoning.text: Mesne profits limited to actual rent Rs.250 pm paid to head lessee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rs.250 was contractual rent, though low; matter between purchaser and head lessee.

holdings.text: Tenancy created by mortgagee does not survive termination of mortgage interest and is not binding on purchaser.
Defendants not protected by East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 as no subsisting tenancy.
Plaintiff entitled to possession; mesne profits at Rs.250 per month from suit date with interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahabir Gope and others v. Hatbans Narain Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports proposition that derivative title from mortgagee ends with mortgagee's title.

precedents_cited.case_name: Asaram and others v. Mst. Ram Kali
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports proposition that derivative title from mortgagee ends with mortgagee's title.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Lease determines on termination of lessor's interest; exception for prudent acts by mortgagee in possession.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Does not protect tenancy that ended with mortgage; definitions of landlord/tenant require subsisting relation.

statutes_cited.name: Evacuee Interest (Separation) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Sale satisfied mortgage debt, extinguishing mortgage interest.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court decree: plaintiff entitled to possession as lease terminated with mortgage; no Rent Act protection; mesne profits fixed at Rs. 250 per month from suit date till possession with 6% interest.
outcome.relief_granted: Possession to plaintiff Raja Gyan Nath; mesne profits at Rs. 250 pm with interest.

key_quotes.text: "A general proposition of law is that no person can confer on another a better title than he himself has."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle applied to mortgagee leases.

key_quotes.text: "The relationship of lessor and lessee cannot subsist beyond the mortgagees interest unless the relationship is agreed to by the mortgagor or a fresh relationship is recreated."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Such a long lease on such a small rent was an act of prudence, whether it was a bona fide act or not, and whether the exception can apply to urban property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
